Heart of the Gila
May 30 at 6:55 PM ·

Hey, Heart of the Gila friends. Please welcome Quinn Crockett our summer, 2020 intern. Quinn will be a senior at Aldo Leopold Charter School in the fall. She grew up and lives at the headwaters of the Gila River in the village of Gila Hot Springs and will help with our stewardship, trails and education projects.
Says Quinn, “I grew up in the wilderness and since the time I could talk I’ve been learning how to identify and use many native plants. I’ve been doing research and projects on invasive species for years now and I’m eager to learn more and support this place that I will forever call my home."

Students at Aldo Leopold Charter School invited members of the public to their Fall Semester Internship Showcase on Dec. 4, 2019, at their new school building on the WNMU campus.

The students each did a short presentation, explaining what they did in their internship and what they learned. Many of the students interned jobs that were similar to one in which they thought they might want to have as a career. Many of them said they would like to continue on that path in their educations, while some said they found out that the job was not what they had thought it would be. Interning is a time for finding out what they really would like to do.

Today- December 1st.
World AIDS Day
Everybody counts. End AIDS
Key facts

HIV continues to be a major global public health issue, having claimed more than 35 million lives so far. In 2016, 1.0 million people died from HIV-related causes globally.
There were approximately 36.7 million people living with HIV at the end of 2016 with 1.8 million people becoming newly infected in 2016 globally.
54% of adults and 43% of children living with HIV are currently receiving lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART).
Global ART coverage for pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV is high at 76% .
The WHO African Region is the most affected region, with 25.6 million people living with HIV in 2016. The African region also accounts for almost two thirds of the global total of new HIV infections.

Can Aldo Leopold’s land ethic tackle our toughest problems?

Justin Bramhall
December 6, 2016 at 5:05 AM ·

"Our challenge, then, is to continue — or better, accelerate — the evolution of the land ethic and the ideas that underpin it. Three generations after Leopold, we’re even more distracted than the people of his time, and our environmental problems are in many ways vastly more complicated and pressing. The biotic community is as interconnected as ever, though our influences upon it are greater now, and voluntary decency must stretch to serve species and places we don’t know and never will. But we can still start in the same place Leopold did: in the chicken coop, and with the problems of the backyard biota."

ALCS 2016 New Mexico History Trip
Aldo Leopold Charter School Students Meet with Attorney General Balderas

Santa Fe, NM – Attorney General Hector Balderas announced that he met with 16 juniors and seniors from Silver City’s Aldo Leopold Charter School at his office in Santa Fe today. The meeting lasted for an hour and forty-five minutes and some of the topics discussed included environmental issues, immigration, fighting corruption, strengthening rural communities and improving state government.

“I was honored to meet with these bright students from Grant County during their trip to Santa Fe,” said Attorney General Balderas. “I was also very impressed with the amount of work and research the students completed ahead of our discussion, and by their dedication to confronting the many issues facing New Mexico and its rural communities.”

Fundrasing Event April 9th from 6 to 8pm

Aldo Leopold Charter School
Middle School Teachers and Students
Invite You To
“Building Our Future”
2016 Fundraising Program and Pledge Drive Dinner

Saturday April 9, 2016
6pm to 8pm
The New Aldo Leopold Middle School Building
2138 Highway 180 East (Formerly “Billy’s)

This No Cost event will have facility tours, dinner, music and inspiring student presentations.

Help support our mission to provide an engaging and challenging educational program emphasizing direct experience, inquiry learning, stimulation of the creative process, and stewardship of our community and natural environment.

We hope you are excited about the future we are building together and will make a generous pledge.

Seating is limited. If you can join us, please RSVP to the school office - 575-538-2542 or email Cathie at - cgomez@aldocs.org
